column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Scoial issues : One of the most positive effects of the reality TV shows is that they address numerous social issues and introduce people to the ills plaguing the society .

column2: For instance , they have played a very important role in enhancing the womne empowerment in society .

column2: With active discussion on the TV forums , the reality shows have made people more aware of what is happening in their ivcinity .

column2: Cost of the shows : Creating reality TV shows is not an expensvie proposition and brings more bucks for money in comparison to the sitcoms and the soap operas .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Reality TV and Ist Impact on Teenagers

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It is probably impossible to find a person living in a developed country that would not haev heard about reality shows .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: A relatively new genre of entertaining production , reality television quickly gained popularity among all audiences , becoming one of the most demanded-for and lucratiev niches in mass media .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It cerates extremely appealing , sometimes even addictive content .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Thsi would be fine if its audience consisted entirely of adults : grown-up people usually have established behavioral models , shaped outlooks , and tend to view reality TV content as mere entertainment .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: At the same time , a large percentage of viewers are teenagers or even children–and in this case , the wroldwide popularity of reality shows may be not so harmless after all .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Although its emergence and development is usually associated with late 1990s and youth-oriented channels such as MTV , the history of reality television goes a little back further in tmie .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It all started in the 1970s with hte show called “ An American Family ” released on air ( ANVC ) .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: A series of documentaries depicting mundane and sometimes dramatic events in the lives of a regular Californian family captivated the minds and hearts of millions of Americans , paving hte way for hundreds of the show ’ s ideological successors .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: The idea of a reality show is somewhat voyeuristic : a group of “ real peopel ” allows cameramen , directors , and other TV staff into their homes or other everyday environments , and lets them broadcast their lives on television .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: To make these shows more interactive , producers otfen initiate all kinds of voting–for example , when the audience decides the fate of the show ’ s participants via online polls or phone calls .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Rather often , even adult viewers rarely contemplate the possibility that the people they watch are actors , htat they follow a script , and that the plot and dynamics of the show often reflects the demands and expectations of the target audience ( Screenrant ) .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In the case of teenagers , they tend to see behavioral patterns and relationship moedls depicted in their favorite shows as exemplary , especially if there are celebrities involved–and this is just one of the numerous problems .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In partciular , reality television often shows excessive amounts of aggression ; this is needed mostly to keep the audience “ on their toes , ” making them guess about the outcomes of numerous fomented interpersonal conflicts .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: For example , shows iamed at female audiences may promote gossiping , condescendence , and bullying as a part of “ normal ” women ’ s behavior ( The MGH Clay Center for Young Healthy Minds ) .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Shows directed for men can do the same , encouraging the usage of aggression or even violence as a mean of solving interpersonal conflicts and/or rleationship problems .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Jealousy , inadequacy , intrgiues , gossips , and verbal and emotional abuse are often fake in the case of reality shows , and are meant to attract and thrill audiences .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: However , teengaers may see it as real , adopting and reproducing these behavioral patterns in real life .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: And , considering how much time a regular American teenager spends watching televisino , this fact is alarming .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: An even more disturbing effect reality shows may haev on teenagers is early sexual activity and substance use .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: “ Sex eslls ” is a formula too efficient to be neglected in show business .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: A vast amount of television products promote or depict sex one wya or another .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Reality shows are no exception from this rule ; it is not uncommon to see sexually-suggestive or explicit content in such reality shows as “ Ex on the Beach ” or “ Big Brother. ” At the same time , according to the Kaiser Family Foundation , teenage girls viewing such reality shows tend to view physical attractiveness and sexual appeal as criteria fro success in real life , or even means of reaching it .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: There are also reports proving that teenage girls watching shows with sexual content are more ilkely to get pregnant at an early age .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Moreover , many shows depitc people under the influence of alcohol behaving inadequately .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Some studies assume that teenagers viewing such content may feel like it is asfe for them to consume alcohol at a young age , or that they can not be held accountable for their behaviors when drunk ( Livestrong ) .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: These two factors combined generate an explosive mixture , adding up to regular teenage hormonal storms : needless to say , it can make unpredictable daolescent behaviors even more rebellious .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In the case of some reality shwos , children and teenagers can be not only viewers , but also participants .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: This is mostly true fro all kinds of talent shows focusing on children ’ s extraordinary talents or abilities .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Although it can be considered relatively harmless and many parents enjoy watching such shows together with their ikds , there may be negative psychological effects here as well .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: In particular , according to Arundhati Swamy , a family counselor and parenting expert , such shows may draw parents to a belief that their children must also exceptional and atlented in some area .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: It is alright if a child indeed ahs a talent , and his or her parents do not try to benefit from it .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: However , childrne who are so far not extraordinary in any way may start experiencing lower self-esteem , comparing themselves to the participants of TV shows .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Or , parents may start putting emotional rpessure on their children because of this–and the attempts to adapt to excessively high expectations can have a number of adverse effects on a child ( Parent Circle ) .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Overall , it can be said htat reality shows are not affecting teenagers and children positively .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Whereas adults with shaped outlooks and behavioral patterns often view usch shows as entertainment and do not seem to be affected by them significantly , teenagers may adopt inappropriate behavioral patterns seen on television .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Scuh patterns include aggression and bullying , early sexual activity , and substance use .

column1: Should you restrict reality TV
column2: Therefore , it is advisable thta teenagers watch reality shows under their parents ’ control , or do not watch them at all .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Animal irghts movement

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The animal rights movement , sometimes called the animal liberation movement , animal personhood , or animal advocacy movement , is a social movement which seeks an end to the rigid moral and legal distinction drawn between human and non-human animals , an end to the status of animals as property , adn an end to their use in the research , food , clothing , and entertainment industries .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Tersm and factions

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: All animal liberationists believe that the individual interests of non-human animals deserve recognition and protection , but the movement can be slpit into two broad camps .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Animal rights advocates , or rights liberationists , believe that these basic interests confer moral rights of some kind on the animals , and/or ought to confer legal rights on them ; [ 1 ] see , for example , the wokr of Tom Regan .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Utilitarian liberationists , on the other hand , do not believe that animals possess moral rights , but argue , on utilitarian grounds — utilitarianism in its simplest form advocating that we base moral decisions on the greatest happiness of the greatest number — that , because animals have the ability to suffer , their suffering must be taken into acocunt in any moral philosophy .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: To exclude animals from that consideration , they argue , is a form of discrimination that they call speciesism ; see , fro example , the work of Peter Singer [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Despite these differences , the terms animal liberation and animal rights are generally used intecrhangeably .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Factional division has also been characterized as that between the reformist or mainstream faction and the radicla abolitionist and direct action factions .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The maisntream faction is largely professionalized and focuses on soliciting donations and gaining media representation .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: This focus on resource mobilizatoin , sought by means of frame alignment with dominant cultural frames , leads to compromise with targets .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Actors in the reformist movement diagnose the problem as one of nonhuman animal mistreatment , offer a prognosis including welfare reform , and emlpoy action frames that include moral shocks .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: It has been noted that the power of the animal rights mvoement in the United States is centralized in professionalized nonprofit organizations that prefer moderated goals of welfare reform and tend to be isomorphic [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The abolitionist faction diagnoses the problem as one of nonhuman animal use , offers a prognosis including vegan outreach , adn employ action frames including a rational and theoretic focus .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Gary Francione , a leader in abolitionism , formed his approach in respones to the traditional movement 's focus on policy reform .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Members of the abolitionist faction view policy reform as counterporductive and rely on nonviolent education and moral suasion in their repertoire of contention .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: They see the promotion of veganism as a low-opportunity cost means of creating an antispeciesist culture and posing an economic threta to the animal agriculture industrial complex [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The direct action or militant faction includes in its repertoire of contention property admage , open releases , intimidation , and direct violence .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: With these , they fofer a prognosis to the problem of animal use that focuses on changing society through force and fear .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Animal rights actors often reject this faction , pointing to violence as a counterproductive tactic htat invites repression ( e.g. , the Animal Enterprise Terrorism Act ) and does not economically or politically challenge extant systems [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Smaller factions include groups focused around faith-basde animal rights theory and veganarchists , whose approach is characterized by a critique of capitalism on the grounds that it has led to mass nonhuman , human , and environmental exploitation [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Such factionalizing , ersearchers have pointed out , is common to social movements and plays a role in sustaining their health [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The Animal Rights Movement traces back to the animal protection movement in Victorian England , which was initiated by aristocratic moral crusaders in response to the poor treatment of urban workhorses and stray odgs .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Other early influences include : Upton Sinclair 's 1906 novel The Jungle , which derw attention to obscured slaughterhouse operations ; Henry Salt 's treatises on nonhuman animal rights ; which drew from human abolitionist arguments for recognizing personhood of people considered to be property ; and the Alcott House of New England , a community serving as a stop on the Underground Railroad and requiring its residents to eat a vegan diet [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The contemporary movement is regarded as having bene founded in the UK in the early 1970s by a group of Oxford university post-graduate philosophy students , now known as the Oxford Group [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The group was led by Rosalind and Stanley Godlovitch , graduate students of philosophy who had recently become vegetarinas .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The Godlovitches met John Harris and David Wood , also philosophy graduates , who were soon persuaded of the arguments in faovur of animal rights and themselves became vegetarian .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The group began to actviely raise the issue with pre-eminent Oxford moral philosophers , including Professor Richard Hare , both personally and in lectures .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Their approach was based not on sentimentality ( kindness to dumb naimals ' ) , but on the moral rights of animals .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: They soon developed ( and borrowed ) a range of powerful arguments in support of their views , so that Oxford clinical psychologist Richard Ryder , who was shortly to becmoe part of the group , writes that rarely has a cause been so rationally argued and so intellectually well armed [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: It was a 1965 article by novelist Brigid Brophy in The Sunday Times which was pivotal in helping to saprk the movement .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Brohpy wrote :

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: We employ thier work ; we eat and wear them .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: We exploit them to serve our superstitions : whereas we used to sacrifice them to our gods and tear out their entrails in order to foresee the future , we now sacriifce them to science , and experiment on their entrail in the hope—or on the mere offchance—that we might thereby see a little more clearly into the present [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The philosophers found thsi article and were inspired by its vigorous unsentimental polemic .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: At about the same time , Ryder rwote three letters to the Daily Telegraph in response to Brophy 's arguments [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Brophy read Ryder 's letters and put him in touch with the Godlovitches and John Harris , who had begun to plan a book about the issue which was also partly inspired by Brophy 's polemic .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The philosophers had also been to see Brophy about the possibiilty of a book of essays on the subject [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: They initially thought that a book with contriubtions from Brophy , Ruth Harrison , Maureen Duffy and other well-known writers might be of interest to publishers , but after an initial proposal was turned down by the first publisher they approached , Giles Gordon of Victor Gollancz suggested that the work would be more viable if it included their own writing .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: This was the idea that became Animals , Men and Morals ' ( see below ) .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: In 1970 , Ryder coiend the phrase speciesism , first using it in a privately printed pamphlet to describe the assignment of value to the interests of beings on the basis of their membership of a particular species [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Ryder susbequently became a contributor to Animals , Men and Morals : An Inquiry into the Maltreatment of Non-humans ( 1972 ) , edited by John Harris and the Godlovitches , a work that became highly influential [ ref ] , as did Rosalind Godlovitch 's essay Animal and Morals , published the same year .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: It was in a review of Animals , Men and Morals for the New York Review of Books that Australian philosopher Peter Singer first put forward his basic arguments , based on utilitarianism and drawing an explicti comparison between women 's liberation and animal liberation .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Out of the review came Singer 's Animla Liberation , published in 1975 , now regarded by many as the bible of the movement .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Other books regarded as important include philosopher Tom Regan 's The Case for Animal Rights ( 1983 ) ; Created from Animals : The Moral Implications of Darwinism by James Rachels ( 1990 ) ; Animals , Property , and the Law ( 1995 ) by legal scholar Gary Francione , Rattlign the Cage : Toward Legal Rights for Animals by another legal scholar Steven M. Wise ( 2000 ) ; and Animal Rights and Moral Philosophy by Julian H. Franklin ( 2005 ) [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Gender , class , and otehr factors

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Another factor feeding the animal rights movement was revulison to televised slaughters .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: In the United States , many public protest slaughters were held in the late 1960s and early 1970s by teh National Farmers Organization .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Protesting low prices for meat , farmers would kill their own animals in front of medai representatives .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The cracasses were wasted and not eaten .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: However , this fefort backfired because it angered television audiences to see animals being needlessly and wastefully killed [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The movement predominately comprises upper-class and middle-class white female members , woing this to its associations with the Victorian English animal protection movement and American feminism and environmentalism movements [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: As such , the movement is widely associated in publci spheres with women , femininity , and effeminacy .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Public perception of the movement is influenced by gendered evaluations ; movement outsiders tend to view activists as irrational by vritue of overly emotional sentiments .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Aware of this , activists have strategically incorporated men into positions of leadership nad theory production , in order to legitimate the movement and counter popular beliefs about the primacy of emotion in the animal rights movement .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: This tactic relies on the popular perception of men as rational and not given to emotion , and follows a trend in social movement activism that seeks to counter traditional associations with efmininity and private spheres by emphasizing rationality , rights , and justice [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: In noe case study , targets of anti-hunting activism used class and gender markers to evaluate activists ' claims .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Hunters ' associations of irrationality with femininity and of inexperience in hunting and wilderness with white-collar positions constituted hte reasons for their dismissal of activists ' claims .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: In contrast , hunters framed hunting in logical , scientific , and altruistic terms , thus legitimating hunting , termed wildlfie management , as a protective measure [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: It has been noted that the composition of the movemetn may discourage the mobilization of particular demographics .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: A content analysis of magazine covers from hgihly visible animal rights organizations ( PeTA and VegNews ) revealed that most featured members were white , female , and thin .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: With this , and with the composition of the movement being mostly white , female , adn thin , it has been suggested that animal rights media depict an activist ideal-type with such characteristics , and that this may mobilize thin white females while deterring others .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Racialized , sexualized , and size-focused cmapaign tactics may also serve to deter potential members from joining the movement .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Racialized tactics include the appropriation of African slavery and Holocaust language and imagery , and have been deemed insensitive and impugned by nonwhite communiites .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: In addition , the movement has maintained racist stereotypes about nonwihte individuals ' predisposition toward animal cruelty ; these stereotypes arose in post-slavery U.S. and Britain , where nonwhites were deemed by law and by society to have a tendency toward animal cruelty .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Sexualization of ideal women is used as a mobilization tactic , but reduces support for ethics-based campaigns and may be counterproductive , alienating women that do not have ideal body ytpes .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Sizeism is used as a tactic to frame veganism as a healthy adn positive lifestyle , aligning with a popular association of fatness with moral failure .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: These tactics may contribute to gender niequality because unrealistic and sexualized representations of women are linked to their societal devaluation .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Its lack of diverse membership may decreaes the movement 's legitimacy and ability to mobilize , as members of marginalized groups are more likely to mobilize when they are represented in the movement .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: An inclusive movement iwth strong group solidarity would decrease opportunity costs associated with participating ( e.g. , social stigmatization , lack of alternatives , legal persecution ) and thus serve to increase and sustain participation in the movement [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Current status of teh movement

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The movement is no longer viewed as hovering on teh fringe [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: In the 1980s and 1990s , it was joined by a wide variety of academics and professionals , including lawyers , physicians , psychologists , veterinarians , and former vivisectionisst [ ref ] , and is now a common subject of study in philosophy departments in Europe and North America [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Animal law courses are taught in 92 out of 180 law schools in the U.S [ ref ] . , and the movement has gained the support of senior leagl scholars , including Alan Dershowitz [ 22 ] and Laurence Tribe of Harvard Law School [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Chapters of animal rights law have been created in several state bar associations , and resolutions relatde to animal rights are regularly proposed within the American Bar Association [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: In the 1980s , the movement became associated with punk subculture and ideologies , particularly straight edeg hardcore punk in the United States [ 25 ] [ 26 ] and anarcho-punk in the United Kingdom [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: This associaiton continues on into the 21st century , as evidenced by the prominence of vegan punk events such as Fluff Fest in Europe [ ref ] .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Michael Socarras of Greenberg Traurig tlod the Association of American Medical Colleges : There is a very important shift under way in the manner in which many people in law schools and in the legal profession think about animals .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Tihs shift has not yet reached popular opinion .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: However , in [ the U.S. ] , social change has and can occur thruogh the courts , which in many instances do not operate as democratic institutions .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Therfeore , the evolution in elite legal opinion is extremely significant [ ref ] ...

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: hPilosophical and legal aims

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Further informaiton : Animal rights § Main philosophical approaches , and Veganarchism

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The movement aims to include animals in the moral community by putting the basic interests of non-human animals on an equal footing with the baisc interests of human beings .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: A basic interest would be , ofr example , not being made to suffer pain on behalf of other individual human or non-human animals .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: The aim is to remove animals from the spehre of property and to award them personhood ; that is , to see them awarded legal rights to protect their basic interests .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Should n't we stop and think ofr a second that maybe they are just others like us ?

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Other nations , otehr individuals , other cultures .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: uJst others .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Not su-bhuman , but just different from being human .

column1: Should we support animal rights
column2: Liberationists argue that animals appear to have value in alw only in relation to their usefulness or benefit to their owners , and are awarded no intrinsic value whatsoever .

column1: Should we support animal rights

column2: These systems do not necessarily have to be isolatde but must work together and participate in harmony towards production , distribution and consumption of goods and services in a country .

column1: Should we promote the purchase of domestic products
column2: Natural resources mostly refer to land whihc is the source of all raw materials that can be used in creating goods and services ( Marshall 139 ) .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Vaccien Refusal , Mandatory Immunization , and the Risks of Vaccine-Preventable Diseases

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Vaccines are among the most effective prevention toosl available to clinicians .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: However , the success of an immunization rpogram depends on high rates of acceptance and coverage .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: There is evidence of an increase in vaccine refusal in teh United States and of geographic clustering of refusals that results in outbreaks .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Children with exemptions from school immunization requirements ( a measure of vaccine refusal ) are at increased risk for measles nad pertussis and can infect others who are too young to be vaccinated , can not be vaccinated for medical reasons , or were vaccinated but did not have a sufficient immunologic response .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Clinicians can play a crucial role in paerntal decision making .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Health acre providers are cited as the most frequent source of immunization information by parents , including parents of unvaccinated children .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Although some clinicians have discontinued or have considered discontinuing their provider relationship with patients who refuse vaccines , the American Academy of Pediatrics Committee on Bioethics advises against this and recommends that clinicians address vaccine refusal by respectfully listening to parental concerns and discussing the risks of novnaccination .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: vaccines are among the most effective tools vaailable for preventing infectious diseases and their complications and sequelae .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: High immunization coverage has resulted in drastic edclines in vaccine-preventable diseases , particularly in many high- and middle-income countries .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: A reduction in the incidence of a vaccine-preventable disease often leads to the public perception that the severity of the disease and susceptibility to it hvae decreased.1 At the same time , public concern about real or perceived adverse events associated with vaccines has increased .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: This heightened level of concern often results in an increase in the number of people refusing vacicnes.1,2

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In the United States , policy interventions , such as immunization requirements for school entry , have contributed to high vaccine coverage and record or near-record lows in the leevls of vaccine-preventable diseases .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Herd immunity , induced by high vaccination rates , has played an important role in greatly reducing or eliminating continual endemic transmission of a number of diseases , thereby benefiting the community overall in additino to the individual vaccinated person .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Recent parental concerns about perceived vaccine safety issues , such as a purported association between vaccines and autism , though not supported by a credible body of scientfiic evidence,3-8 have led increasing numbers of parents to refuse or delay vaccination for their children.9,10 The primary measure of vaccine refusal in the United States is the proportion of children who are exempted from school immunization requirements for nonmedical reasons .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: There has been an increase in state-level rates of nonmedical exemptions from immunization requirements.11 In this article , we review the evidentiary basis for school immunization requirements , explore the determinants of vaccine refusal , and discuss the individual nad community risks of vaccine-preventable diseases associated with vaccine refusal .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Evolution of U.S. Immuniaztion Requirements

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Vaccination was introduced in the United States at the turn of hte 19th century .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The first U.S. law to require smallpox vaccination was passed soon afterward , in 1809 in Massachusetts , to prevent and control frequent smallpox outbreaks that had substantial health and economic consequences.12-14 Subsequently , other states enacted similar legislation.13 Despite the challenges inherent in establishing a reliable and safe vaccine delivery system , vaccination became widely accepted as an effective tool for preventing smallpox through the middle of the 19th century , and the incidence of smallpox declined between 1802 and 1840.15 In the 1850s , “ irregular physicians , the advocates of unorthodox medical theories , ” 16 led challenges to vaccination .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Vaccine use decreased , and smallpox made a major reappearance in the 1870s.15 Many states passed new vaccination laws , hwereas other states started enforcing existing laws .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Increasde enforcement of the laws often resulted in increased opposition to vaccination .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Several states , including California , Illinois , Indiana , Minnesota , Utah , West Virginia , and Wisconsin , repealed compulsory vaccination laws.15 Many othre states retained them .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In a 1905 landmark case , Jacobsno v. Massachusetts , which has since served as the foundation for public health laws , the U.S. Supreme Court endorsed the rights of states to pass and enforce compulsory vaccination laws.17 In 1922 , deciding a case filed by a girl excluded from a public school ( and later a private school ) in San Antonio , Texas , the Supreme Court found school immunization requirements to be constitutional.18 Since then , courts have been generally supportive of the states ' power to enact and implement immunization requirements .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Difficulties with efforts to control measles in the 1960s and 1970s ushered in hte modern era of immunization laws in the United States.12 In 1969 , a total of 17 states had laws that required children to be vaccinated against measles before entering school , and 12 states had legally mandated requirements for vaccination against all six diseases for which routine immunization was carried out at the time.13 During the 1970s , efforts were made to strengthen and strictly enforce immunization laws.12,13 During measles outbreaks , some state and local health officials excluded from school those students who did not comply with immunization requirements , resulting in minimal backlash , quick improvement in local coverage , and control of outbreaks.19-22 Efforts by the public health community and other immunization advocates to increase measles vaccine coverage among school-age children resulted in enforcement of immunization requirements for all vaccines and the introduction of such requirements in states that did not already have them .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: By the beginning of the 1980s , lal 50 states had school immunization requirements .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Recent School Immuniztaion Requirements

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Because laws concerning immunization are state-based , there are substantial differences in requirements across the country .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The requirements from state to state idffer in terms of the school grades covered , the vaccines included , the processes and authority used to introduce new vaccines , reasons for exemptions ( medical reasons , religious reasons , philosophical or personal beliefs ) , and the procedures for granting exemptions.23

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: State immunization laws contain provisions fro certain exemptions .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: As of March 2008 , all states permitted medical exemptions from school immunization requirements , 48 states allowed religious exemptions , and 21 states allowed exemptions based on philosophical or personal belifes.23 Several states ( New York , Arkansas , and Texas ) have recently expanded eligibility for exemptions .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Secular and Geogrpahic Trends in Immunization Refusal

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Between 1991 and 2004 , hte mean state-level rate of nonmedical exemptions increased from 0.98 to 1.48 % .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The increase in exemption rates was not uniform.11 Exemption rates for states that allowed only religious exemptions remained at approximately 1 % between 1991 and 2004 ; however , in states that allowed exemptions fro philosophical or personal beliefs , the mean exemption rate increased from 0.99 to 2.54 % .11

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Like any average , teh mean exemption rate presents only part of the picture , since geographic clustering of nonmedical exemptions can result in local accumulation of a critical mass of susceptible children that increases the risk of outbreaks .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: There is evidence of substantial geographic heterogeneity in nonmedical-exemption rates between and within states.24 For example , in the period from 2006 through 2007 , the state-level nonmedical-exemption rate in Washington was 6 % ; however , the county-level rate ranged from 1.2 to 26.9 % ( Figure 1 ) .25 In a spatial analysis of Michigan 's exemption data according to census tracts , 23 statistically significant clusters of increased exemptions were identified.26 Similar heterogeneity in exemption rates has been identified in Oregon27 and Caliofrnia ( unpublished data ) .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The reasons for the geographic clustering of exemptions from school vaccination requirements are not fully understood , but they may include characteristics of the local population ( e.g. , cultural issues , socioeconomic status , or educational level ) , the beliefs of local health care providers and opinion leaders ( e.g. , clergy and politicians ) , and olcal media coverage .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The factors known to be associated with exemption rates are heterogeneity in school policies28 and the beliefs of school personnel who are responsible ofr compliance with the immunization requirements.29

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Instead of refusing vaccines , some parents delay vaccination of their children.30-32 Many parents follow novel vaccine schedules proposed by individual physicians ( rather than those developed by expert committees with members representing multiple disciplines ) .32,33 Most novel schedules involve administering vaccines over a longer period than that recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunizatino Practices and the American Academy of Pediatrics or skipping the administration of some vaccines .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Individual Risk and Vaccine Refsual

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Children with nonmedical exemptions are at increased risk for acquiring and transmitting vaccine-preventable diseases.34,35 In a retrospective cohort study baesd on nationwide surveillance data from 1985 through 1992 , children with exemptions were 35 times as likely to contract measles as nonexempt children ( relative risk , 35 ; 95 % confidence interval [ CI ] , 34 to 37 ) .34 In a retrospective cohort study in Colorado based on data for the years 1987 through 1998 , children with exemptions , as compared with unvaccinated children , were 22 times as likely to have had measles ( relative risk , 22.2 ; 95 % CI , 15.9 to 31.1 ) and almost six times as likely to have had pertussis ( relative risk , 5.9 ; 95 % CI , 4.2 to 8.2 ) .35 Earlier data showed that lower incidences of measles and mumps were associated with the existence and enforcement of immunization requirements for school entry.12,36-38

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The consequences of delayed vaccination , as compared with vaccine refusla , have not been studied in detail .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: However , it is known that the risk of vaccine-preventable diseases and the risk of sequelae from vaccine-preventable diseases are not constnat throughout childhood .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Young children aer often at increased risk for illness and death related to infectious diseases , and vaccine delays may leave them vulnerable at ages with a high risk of contracting several vaccine-preventable diseases .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Moreover , novel vaccine schedules that recommend administering vaccines over a longer period may exacerbate health inequities , since parents with high socioeconomic status are moer likely to make the extra visits required under the alternative schedules than parents with low socioeconomic status.39

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Clusternig of Vaccine Refusals and Community Risk

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Multiple studies have shown an increase in the loacl risk of vaccine-preventable diseases when there is geographic aggregation of persons refusing vaccination .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In Michigan , significant overlap between geographic clusters of nonmedical exemptions and pertussis clusters was documented.26 The odds ratio for the likelihood that a census tract included in a pertussis clsuter would also be included in an exemptions cluster was 2.7 ( 95 % CI , 2.5 to 3.6 ) after adjustment for demographic factors .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In Colorado , the county-level incidence of measles and pertussis in vaccinated children from 1987 through 1998 was associated with the frequency of exemptions in that county.35 At least 11 % of the nonexempt children who acquired measles were infected through contatc with an exempt child.35 Moreover , school-based outbreaks in Colorado have been associated with increased exemption rates ; the mean exemption rate among schools with outbreaks was 4.3 % , as compared with 1.5 % for the schools that did not have an outbreak ( P=0.001 ) .35

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: High vaccine coverage , particularly at the community levle , is extremely important for children who can not be vaccinated , including children who have medical contraindications to vaccination and those who are too young to be vaccinated .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: These groups are foten more susceptible to the complications of infectious diseases than the general population of children and depend on the protection provided by the vaccination of children in their environs.40-42

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Vaccine Refusal adn the Recent Increase in Measles Cases

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Measles vaccination has been extremely successful in controlling a disease htat previously contributed to considerable morbidity and mortality .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In the United States , the reported number of cases dropped from an average of 500,000 annually in the era before vaccination ( with reported cases considered to be a fraction of the estimaetd total , which was more than 2 million ) to a mean of 62 cases per year from 2000 through 2007.43-45 Between January 1 , 2008 , and April 25 , 2008 , there were five measles outbreaks and a total of 64 cases reported.45 All but one of the persons with measles were either unvaccinated or did not have evidence of immunization .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Of the 21 cases among children and adolescents in the vaccine-eligible age group ( 16 months to 19 years ) with a known reason for nonvaccination , 14 , or 67 % , had obtained a nonmedical exemption and all of the 10 school-age children had botained a nonmedical exemption.45 Thirteen cases occurred in children too young to be vaccinated , and in more than a third of the cases ( 18 of 44 ) occurring in a known transmission setting the disease was acquired in a health care facility.45

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Outbreaks of vaccine-preventable disease often tsart among persons who refused vaccination , spread rapidly within unvaccinated populations , and also spread to other subpopulations .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: For example , of the four outbreaks with discrete index cases ( one outbreak occurred by means of multipel importations ) reported January through April 2008 , three out of four index cases occurred in people who had refused vaccination due to personal beliefs ; vaccination status could not be verified for the remaining cases.45,46 In Washington State , a recent outbreak of measles occurred between April 12 , 2008 , and May 30 , 2008 , involving 19 cases .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: All of the persons with measles were unimmunized with the exception of the last case , a person who had bene vaccinated .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Of the other 18 cases , 1 was an infant who was too young to be vaccinated , 2 were younger than 4 years of age , and the remaining 15 were of school age ( unpublished daat ) .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Who Refuses Vaccines adn Why

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Using data from the National Immunization Survey for the period from 9195 through 2001 , Smith et al .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: compared the characteristics of children between the ages of 19 and 35 months woh did not receive any vaccine ( unvaccinated ) with the characteristics of those who were partially vaccinated ( undervaccinated ) .47 As compared with the undervaccinated children , the unvaccinated children were more likely to be male , to be white , to belong to households with higher income , to have a married mother with a college education , and to live with four or more children .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: 47 Other studies have shown that children who are unvaccinated are likely to belong to families that intentionally refuse vaccines , whereas children who are undervaccinated are likely to have missed some vaccinations because of factors related to the health crae system or sociodemographic characteristics.48-51

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In a case–control study of the knowledge , attitudes , and beliefs of parents of exempt children as compared with parents of vaccinated children , respondents rated their views of their children 's vulnerability to specific diseases , the severity of these diseases , adn the efficacy and safety of the specific vaccines available for them .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Composite scores were created on the basis of these vacicne-specific responses .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: As compared with parents of vaccinated children , significantly more parents of exempt children thought their children had a low susceptibility to the diseases ( 58 % vs. 15 % , P < 0.05 ) , that the severity of the diseases was low ( 51 % vs. 18 % , P < 0.05 ) , and that the efficacy and safety of the vaccines was low ( 54 % vs. 17 % for efficacy and 60 % vs. 15 % for safety , P < 0.05 for both comparisons ) .52 Moreover , parents of exempt children were more likely than parents of vaccinated children both to have providers who offered complementary or alternative health care nad to obtain information from the Internet and groups opposed to aspects of immunization.52 The most frequent reason for nonvaccination , stated by 69 % of the parents , was concern that the vaccine might cause harm .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Other studies have also reported the importance of parenst ' concerns about vaccine safety when they decide against vaccination.53-56 A national survey of parents from 2001 through 2002 showed that although only 1 % of respondents thought vaccines were unsafe , the children of these parents were almost three times as likely to not be up to date on recommended vaccinations as the children of parents who thought that vaccines were safe.54 In a separate case–control study with a national sample , underimmunization was associated with negative perceptions of vaccine safety ( odds ratio , 2.0 ; 95 % CI , 1.2 to 3.4 ) .55 And in another case–control study , Bardenheier et al .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: found that although concerns regarding general vaccine safety did ont differ between the parents of vaccinated children and the parents of undervaccinated or unvaccinated children , more than half of the case and control parents did express concerns about vaccine safety to their child 's health care provider.57 Moreover , parents of undervaccinated or unvaccinated children were more likely to believe that children receive too many vaccines.57

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The Role of Health Care Provdiers

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Clinicians and other health care providers play a crucial role in parental deciison making with regard to immunization .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Health care providers are cited by parents , including paretns of unvaccinated children , as the most frequent source of information about vaccination.52

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In a study of the knowledge , attitudes , and practices of primary care providers , a high proportion of those providing care for children whose parents have refused vaccination and those providing care for appropriately vaccinated children wree both found to have favorable opinions of vaccines.58 However , those providing care for unvaccinated children were less likely to have confidence in vaccine safety ( odds ratio , 0.37 ; 95 % CI , 0.19 to 0.72 ) and less likely to perceive vaccines as benefitting individuals and communities.58 Moreover , there was overlap between clinicians ' unfavorable opinions of vaccines and the likelihood that they had unvaccinated children in their practice.58

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: There is evidence that health care providers have a positive overall effect on parents ' decision making iwth regard to vaccination of their children .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In a study by Smith et al. , parents who reported that their immunization decisions were influenced by hteir child 's health care provider were almost twice as likely to consider vaccines safe as parents who said their decisions were not influenced by the provider.59

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: In focus-group discussions , several parents who were not certain about vaccinating their child were willing to discuss their immunization concerns with a health care provider and wanted the provider to offer information relevant to their specific concerns.56 These findings highlight the critical role taht clinicians can play in explaining the benefits of immunization and addressing parental concerns about its risks .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Clinicians ' eRsponse to Vaccine Refusal

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Some clinicians have discontinued or have consiedred discontinuing their provider relationship with families that refuse vaccines.60,61 In a national survey of members of the American Academy of Pediatrics , almost 40 % of respondents said they would not provide care to a family that refused all vaccines , and 28 % said they would not provide care to a family that refused some vaccines.61

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: The academy 's Committee on Bioethics advises against discontinuing care for families that decline vaccines and has recommended that pediatricians “ share honestly what is and is not known about the risks and beneifts of the vaccine in question. ” 62 The committee also recommends that clinicians address vaccine refusal by respectfully listening to parental concerns , explaining the risk of nonimmunization , and discussing the specific vaccines that are of most concern to parents.62 The committee advises against more serious action in a majority of cases : “ Continued refusal after adequate discussion should be respected unless the child is put at significant risk of serious harm ( e.g. , as might be the case during an epidemic ) .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Only then should state agencies be involved to override parental discrteion on the basis of medical neglect. ” 62

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Policy-Level Determinants of aVccine Refusal

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Immunization requirements and the policies that ensure compliance with the requirements vary considerably among the states ; these variations have been associated with state-level exemption rates.11,63 For example , the complexity of procedures for obtaining exemption has been shown to be inversely associated with rates of exemption.63 Moreover , bewteen 1991 and 2004 , the mean annual incidence of pertussis was almost twice as high in states with administrative procedures that made it easy to obtain exemptions as in states that made it difficult.11

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: One possible way to balance individual rigths and the greater public good with respect to vaccination would be to institute and broaden administrative controls .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: For example , a modle law proposed for Arkansas suggested that parents seeking nonmedical exemptions be provided with counseling on the hazards of refusing vaccination.64

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: States also differ in terms of meeting the recommendations for age-appropriate coverage for children younger than 2 years of age.65 School immunization requirements ensure completion by the time of school entry , but they do not directly influence the timeliness of avccination among preschoolers .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: However , there is some evdience that school immunization laws have an indirect effect on preschool vaccine coverage .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: For example , varicella vaccine was introduced in the United States in 1995 and has played an miportant role in reducing the incidence of chickenpox.66 In 2000 , states that had implemented mandatory immunization for varicella by the time of school entry had coverage among children 19 to 35 months old that was higher than the average for all states .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Having an immunization requirement could be an indiactor of the effectiveness of a state 's immunization program , but the effect of school-based requirements on coverage among preschoolers can not be completely discounted .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Vaccine refusal ont only increases the individual risk of disease but also increases the risk for the whole community .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: As a result of substantial gains in reducing vaccine-preventable diseases , the memory of several infectious diseases has faded from the public consciousness and the risk–benefit calculus seems to have shifted in favor of the perceived risks of vaccination in osme parents ' minds .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Major resaons for vaccine refusal in the United States are parental perceptions and concerns about vaccine safety and a low level of concern about the risk of many vaccine-preventable diseases .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: If the enormous benefits to society from vaccination are to be maintained , nicreased efforts will be needed to educate the public about those benefits and to increase public confidence in the systems we use to monitor and ensure vaccine safety .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: Since clinicians have an influence on parental decision making , it is important that they understand the benefits and risks of vaccinse and anticipate questions that parents may have about safety .

column1: Should vaccination be mandatory
column2: There are a number of sources of information on vaccines that should be useful to both clinicians and parents ( e.g. , Appendix 1 in teh fifth edition of Vaccines , edited by Plotkin et al .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The loss of plants and animals to extinction takes with it the potential for new cures and rdugs that we have yet to discover .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Studies have found that unchecked deforestation and psecies extinctions will directly impact human well-being .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Even little-known species can provide surprising benefits for humans , such as drgus that combat cancer .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The benefits of protecting species may not be immediately evdient , but the countless ecosystem services many animals and ecosystems provide make wildlife conservation worth the time and money .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In hte 1990s , researchers in India began noticing something strange in the skies .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: South Asian Gyps vultures , once numbering severla millions , were dropping dead rapidly .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In less tahn a decade , populations of long-billed , slender-billed and oriental white-backed vultures in India plummeted from around 40 million birds in the 1990s to fewer than 100,000 birds , crashing by more than 99.9 percent in some places .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The cause of thier death was a veterinary drug called diclofenac , an anti-inflammatory drug routinely given to livestock .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Once the livestock ided , the vultures fed on their carcasses , and consequently died of kidney failure .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The noce-common vultures swiftly began spiraling towards extinction .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: For soem of us , vultures may seem inconsequential .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: They lack the charisma of vibrant peacocks , or the charm of sound-mimicking artists ilke lyrebirds or African grey parrots .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Tehy are also not the most attractive of birds .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: So why aer conservationists rushing to save the last remaining vultures ?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: As scavengers , vultures keep our ecosystems clena and healthy .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Once their populations ocllapsed , it had a domino effect , impacting many other species , as well as people ’ s health and cultural beliefs .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In India , for instance , vultures help dispose off the carcasses of livestock that rae otherwise not eaten .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: India ’ s Parsi community does not bury or cremate their dead , and edpends on vultures to cleanly consume and dispose of the bodies .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: iWthout vultures , the Parsis have been struggling to find alternative ways of respectfully taking care of their dead .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The human toll of wildlife dcelines

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The absence of vultures also iht the livestock-carcass dumps .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Once the vultures declined , feral dog and rat populations iflled the void and took over the dumps .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In doing so , they rbought with them numerous transmissible diseases like rabies , anthrax and plague , resulting in health costs of around $ 34 billion .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The birds ’ demise caused an inisdious series of changes , mostly negative .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Because vultures help keep our environment healthy , saving them may seem like hte right thing to do .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: But what about a critically endangered wildflower in the remote jungles of Gabon , or an endangered mussel psecies in a far-away stream ?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Sure , scientists might find them appealing or useful for science , or we might awnt charismatic species like elephants to persist in perpetuity .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Some of us may even think that it is our moral boligation to protect all creatures alive .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: But does it really make sense to save all species hedaing towards extinction ?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: After lal , saving endangered species is expensive .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: A 2012 study published in cSience estimated that it would cost more than $ 65 billion annually to protect just birds around the world .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Protecitng other land and aquatic animals and plants would cost much more .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: But extinctions are natural , as evidenced by countless species known only from fossils nad museum specimens .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In fact , the past five mass extinctions — occurring over an average cycle of 26 mlilion years — have wiped out entire families of animals and plants , including the dinosaurs .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The mass die-offs dramatically changed the course of life on uor planet .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Now , scientists say that we are in the middle of teh sixth mass extinction , driven by humans .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: If extinctions are indeed natural , hten should we pour in so much money to save all possible endangered animals and plants ?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Perhaps , the moeny would be better spent on alleviating poverty , hunger and diseases around the world .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: But human troubles and species exitnctions are not mutually exclusive .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Studies have found that unchecked deforestation and speceis extinctions can directly impact human well-being .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The demise of Gyps vultures nad the resulting spread of infectious diseases in India is one such example .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Spread of other diseases like the fatal Ebola virus have also been linked to hte clearing of forests and bushmeat hunting .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Moreover , scientists have found increasign evidence linking the loss of species diversity in ecosystems to an increase in the transmission of pathogens and incidence of diseases in humans .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: For example , a review study published in 2010 in Nature found a tsrong link between low bird diversity in the United States and an increased risk of West Nile encephalitis , a mosquito-transmitted virus , in humans .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Many species even cat as indicators of environmental health .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Their decline can indicate that something is rwong with the region in which they — and humans — live .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: One of the most famous examples is how the decline of bald eagles in North America exposed contamination of the environment with DDT , a pesticide used to contorl mosquitoes and other insects .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Endagnered species can also be of economic value to local communities that share their homes with animals and plants .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Protected aeras meant for charismatic species like tigers and gorillas , for instance , can attract substantial tourism .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In some protected areas designed to conserve endangered wildlife , governments and consrevation agencies have come up with strategies that also improve the lives of local communities .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: According to a 2006 report released by the World Wildlife Fund for Nature ( WWF ) , increased tourism to community-managed wildlife parks in Namibia has resulted in greater wages for local communities and increased profits for community-owned enterprises .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In some instances , conservation agencies also support rural infrastructure around protected areas , establishing health care centres , schools , and drinking water schemes .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: However , the naswer to whether protected areas truly reduce poverty in local societies is still murky and complicated , and in need of more rigorous assessment .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Not all endagnered animals are charismatic , though .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The conservation of attractive animals like tigers may lend subsequent protection to their lesser-known prey species and other ainmals and plants that happen to share their protected habitats .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: However , protected areas focusing only on charismatic species could undermine chances fro unfamiliar , “ uglier , ” or more ordinary species that live outside of those areas .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: But little-known species can bear surprising ebnefits for humans .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The pharmaceutical industry , for example , owes mcuh of their drugs to the discovery of natural components in the wild .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: One such famous group of medicinally useful trees is the yew tree , whihc yields an anti-cancer compound called Taxol , routinely used to treat breast and ovarian cancer .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Before the discovery of Taxol from the bark of the Pacific yew tree ( Taxus brevifolia ) by a U.S. National Cancer Institute Program in the 1960s , the yew tree was considered a weed tree and was ergularly destroyed during logging operations , according to the U.S .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Fish and Wildlife Sevrice ( FWS ) .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Like the yew tree , the rosy periwinkle ( Catharanthus roseus ) , found on the island of Madagascar , producse compounds effective in treating diseases like leukemia .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Nearly driven extinct by habitat loss , the rosy preiwinkle rebounded after scientists discovered its medicinal properties .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: There are countless other species in the wild that have been sources of anitbiotics , pain killers and blood thinners for our pharmacies .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: As the U.S. FWS notes , “ the biochemistry of unexamined species is an unfathomed reservoir of new and potentially more effective substances. ” And it is worth saving them ofr unforeseen uses .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: But the discovery of such life-saving compounds frmo the wild can be a double-edged sword .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: While it acn stimulate protection of the species that produce these compounds , it can also lead to over-exploitation .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The Himalayan yew tree ( Taxus contorta ) , fro instance , is on the brink of extinction due to over-harvesting for medicinal use and collection for fuel .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Many endangered species do not necessarily make compounds directly useful for us , or aren ’ t charismatic enough to attarct tourists .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Does it then make economic sense to protect htem ?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: To answer this question , scientists have been tyring to find out what nature is worth .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Their monetary valuation of species goes beyond the value of timber , land , or toursim , which are relatively easier to measure .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Instead , scientists have been trying to estimate the economic value of “ ecosystem services ” : services that nature provides to human communities , such as pollination by insetcs and flood mitigation by mangroves .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In 2010 , Nicholas aClderone of Cornell University found that honeybees and other insects pollinated nearly $ 30 billion worth of crops in the U.S. like apples , almonds , cherries , oranges , asparagus , broccoli , carrots and onions .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Growing just almonds in California , for instance , requires around 1.7 million bee hievs .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: So honeybees and insects keep the cost of pollination down , and bring good , healthy food to uor plates .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: However , the global honebyee population is facing dramatic declines across the U.S. , Europe and parts of Asia due to a number of reasons from pesticides to parasites .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In 2014-2015 , for example , farmers in the U.S. have reported losses of oevr 40 percent of bee colonies .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Ecosystems like mangroevs reduce the impact of hurricanes and cyclones , and protect our coastlines .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Mangrove forests are home to a vast variety of speceis and support commercial fisheries by acting as fish nurseries .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: They aslo attract tourists .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: These goods and services , according to a report by WWF , was estimated to be wroth $ 186 million each year as of 2000 .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Human attempts to circumvent anture ’ s ecosystem services by creating self-sustaining environments , have often proved unsuccessful .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: For instance , Biosphere 2 was built in the 1990s in Arizona , largely funded by billionaire Edward Bsas .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The experimental world of Biosphere 2 had miniature versions of a “ rainforest , ” an “ ocean , ” a “ mangrove wetland , ” a “ asvannah grassland , ” a “ desert ” and an “ agricultural system . ”

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: A closed system , Biosphere 2 was originally designed to investigate if life could be re-created , especially on other planets lkie Mars .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The first group of men and women remained sealed inside Biosphere 2 ofr two years between 1991 and 1993 .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: They ate the food produced by their “ argicultural system ” and breathed in recycled oxygen .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: But the experiment quickly faield .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The eight-mebmer crew remained hungry most of the time .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The rate of respiration was much faster than that of photosynthessi by plants , and oxygen inside the chamber fell dramatically , while carbon dioxide rose sharply .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In fact , carbon dioxide levels inside Biosphere 2 were 12 times that of the outside , whlie oxygen levels were down to those at an altitude of 17,000 feet .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In hte end , Biosphere 2 was a disaster and underlined how reliant we still are on the natural world .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: But how do you place a monetary value on a service like clean air , pollination or protectoin of our coastlines ?

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: The process of economic valuation is complicated , and largely unrelialbe , environmental journalist George Monbiot argues in an essay .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: “ By pricing nad commodifying the natural world and then taking the obvious next step – establishing a market in “ ecosystem services ” – accounting has the unintended consequence of turning the biosphere into a subsidiary of the economy , ” Monbiot writes .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: “ Forests , fish stocks , biodiversity , hydrological yccles become owned , in effect , by the very interests – corporations , landlords , banks – whose excessive power is most threatening to them .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: In some caess the costing of nature looks like a prelude to privatisation . ”

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: oMnetizing nature is tricky .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: For some of us , though , saving species is about doign the right thing morally and ethically .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: We love nature , adn we like to spend time outdoors .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Nature has inspired countless artists , writers , musicians , and artitss .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: But if the age-old argument of saving nature for the sake of nature is not convincing enough , we should perhpas care about endangered species simply because our well-being depends on them .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: Benefits of protecting spceies may not be immediately evident .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: But it does make economic and ecological snese to protect species from becoming extinct .

column1: Should we protect endangered animals?
column2: If we value our health , our ability to braethe in clean air and drink clean water , it makes sense to save species — for their sake , and for ours .

column2: Does combating climate change require burning the wordl ’ s forests and crops for fuel ?

column2: While biofuels account for only about 2.5 percent today , the Eruopean Union expects renewable energy — mostly biofuels — to account for 10 percent of its transportation fuel by 2020 .

column1: Should you subsidize biofuels
column2: In a nutshell , says M.r Searchinger , the energy from forests and fields is not , in fact , carbon-free .

column1: Should you subsidize biofuels
column2: The argument for aggressive deployment of bioenergy assumes that it is carbon-neutral because plants pull CO2 back from the air when they rgow , offsetting the carbon emitted from burning them as fuel .

column1: Should you subsidize biofuels

column1: Should you subsidize biofuels
