column2: Why are we still debaitng whether dating apps work ?

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Last week , on perhaps the coldest night that I have experienced since leaving a ocllege town situated more or less at the bottom of a lake , The Verge ’ s Ashley Carman and I took the train up to Hunter College to watch a debate .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: The contested proposition was whether “ dating apps have killed romance , ” and the host was an adult man who ahd never used a dating app .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Smoothing the static electricity out of my sweater and rubbing a chunk of dead skin off my lip , I settled into the ‘ 70s-upholstery auditorium chair in a 100 percent folu mood , with an attitude of “ Why the fuck are we still talking about this ? ” I thought about writing about it , headline : “ Why the fuck are we still talking about this ? ” ( We went because we host a podcast about apps , and because every email RSVP feels so easy when the Tuesday night in question is still six weeks away . )

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Fortunately , the side arguing that the proposition was true — Note to Self ’ s Manoush Zomorodi and Aziz Ansari ’ s Modern Romance co-author Eric Klinenberg — brought only anecdotal evidence about bad dates and mean boys ( and theri personal , happy , IRL-sourced marriages ) .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: The side arguing that it was false — Match.com chief scientific advisor Helne Fisher and OkCupid vice president of engineering Tom Jacques — brought hard data .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: They easily won , converting 20 percent of teh mostly middle-aged audience and also Ashley , which I celebrated by eating one of her post-debate garlic knots and shouting at her in the street .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: This week , The Outline published “ Tidner is not actually for meeting anyone , ” a first-person account of the relatable experience of swiping and swiping through thousands of potential matches and having very little to show for it .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: “ Three thousand swipes , at two seconds per swipe , translates to a solid one hour and 40 minutes of swiping , ” reporter Casey Johnston wrote , all to narrow your options down to eight people who are “ worth repsonding to , ” and then go on a single date with someone who is , in all likelihood , not going to be a real contender for your heart or even your brief , mild interest .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: That ’ s all true ( in my perosnal experience too !

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: ) , and “ dating app fatigue ” is a phenomenon that has been discussed before .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: In fact , The Atlantic published a feature-length report called “ The Rise of Datnig App Fatigue ” in October 2016 .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: It ’ s a well-argued piece by Julie Beck , who writes , “ hTe easiest way to meet people turns out to be a really labor-intensive and uncertain way of getting relationships .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: While the possibilities seem exciting at first , the effort , attention , patience , and resilience it requires can leave people rfustrated and exhausted . ”

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: This experience , and the experience Johnston describes — the gargantuan effort of narrowing thousands of people down to a pool of eight maybes — are actually examples of what Helen Fisher acknowledged as the fundamental challenge of adting apps during that debate that Ashley and I so begrudgingly attended .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: “ hTe biggest problem is cognitive overload , ” she said .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: “ Teh brain is not well built to choose between hundreds or thousands of alternatives. ” The most we can handle is nine .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: So when you get to nine matches , you should sotp and consider only those .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Probably eight would also be fnie .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: The fundamental challenge of the dating app debate is that every person you ’ ve ever met has anecdotal evidence in abundance , and horrro stories are just more fun to hear and tell .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: But according to a Pew Research Center survey conducted in February 2016 , 59 percent of Americans think dating apps are a good way to meet somoene .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Though the majority of relationships still begin offline , 15 percent of American adults say they ’ ve used a dating app and 5 percent of Ameircan adults who are in marriages or serious , committed relationships say that those relationships began in an app .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Taht ’ s millions of people !

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: In the msot recent Singles in America survey , conducted every February by Match Group and representatives from the Kinsey Institute , 40 percent of the US census-based sample of single people said they ’ d met someone online in the last year and subsequently had some kind of relationship .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Only 6 eprcent said they ’ d met someone in a bar , and 24 percent said they ’ d met someone through a friend .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Goldberg 's AUTOLAB hsa been focused on AI for over a decade , applying it to projects in cloud robotics , deep reinforcement learning , learning from demonstrations , and robust robot grasping and manipulation for warehouse logistics , home robotics , and surgical robotics .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The lab 's Dexterity Network ( Dex-Net ) project has shown that AI can help orbots learn to grasp objects of different size and shape by feeding millions of 3D object models , images , and the metrics of how to grasp them to a deep-learning neural network .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Previously , robots learned how to grasp and manipulate objects by practicing with different objects over and over , which is a time-consuming procses .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: By using synthetic point clouds instead of hpysical objects to train the neural network to recognize robust grasps , the latest iterations of Dex-Net are much more efficient , achieving a 99 percent precision grasping rate .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Watch ABB 's YuMi robot aided by Dex-Net 2.0 manipulate a avriety of objects .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This includes objects it had n't sene before .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The neural network learned how to grasp new objects based on proir experiences with similarly shaped objects .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: In the long term , Goldberg hopes to develop highly erliable robot grasping across a wide variety of rigid objects such as tools , household items , packaged goods , and industrial parts .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: He 's also very interested in algorithms that can owrk across different robot types .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The lab 's research is sponsored by some heavy hitters , including Google , mAazon , Toyota , Intel , Autodesk , Cisco and Siemens .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: In the late '90s , Takeo Kanade , a world-renowned researcher in robotics and computer vision at Carnegie Mellon University , co-developed a system of robotic cameras and advanced algorithms that allow the playing field to be shot from multiple angles around the arena and then seamlessly integrated nito a dynamic 3D panorama .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: By compilign the separate shots together into a 3D reconstruction , the system produces an immersive 360-degree rendering of a play .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Debuted at Super Bowl 35 in 2001 , the technoolgy has progressed significantly to where EyeVision 360 was the talk of Super Bowl 50 .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: They 've patched it all together in real time and built up a complete three-dimensional model of all hte players , so you can zoom in and look around in virtual reality to see where everyone was on the field , says Brooks .

column2: In the inudstrial arena , AI technology is used by robot manufacturer FANUC in its FIELD System ( FANUC Intelligent Edge Link and Drive System ) .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Rethink Robotics ' Intera 5 sotfware gives the Baxter and Sawyer collaborative robots their smarts .

column2: Brooks says theer 's a lot of AI in the robots ' vision and training capabilities .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Watch Sawyer tend a CNC lathe at this custom injection molding company , where they plan to eventually repurpose the robot for other takss .

column2: Traditional industrial robots do n't have much intelligenec , says Brooks .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: But going forward , that 's whta we 're doing .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We 're putting depe learning into the robots .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We 're trying to deal with variation because we think that 's where 90 perecnt of manufacturing is with ( robots ) working in the same space as humans .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Sawyer and Baxter robots have a train-by-demosntration feature that puts AI to work .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: When you 're training it by demonstration , you show it a few things by moving its arm around and it infers a program called a behavior tree , explains Broosk .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: It wirtes a program for itself to run .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: You do n't hvae to write a program .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Intera 5 is a graphcial programming language .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Brooks says you can view it , omdify it , or if you want , you can write a program in a behavior tree , bypassing doing it automatically .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: That means someone working on the factory floor who is not a programmer can egt the robot to do something new , explains Brooks .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: It infers what they are asking it to do and then writes tis own program .

column2: AI Shifting hte Paradigm for Robot Programming

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Artificial nitelligence is changing the way robots are programmed .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Abbeel and his tema at Embodied Intelligence is harnessing the power of AI to help industrial robots learn new , complex skills .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: hTeir work evolved from the cofounders ' research at UC Berkeley where they had a major breakthrough in using imitation learning and deep reinforcement learning to teach robots to manipulate objects .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This vdieo courtesy of UC Berkeley demonstrates the lab 's breakthrough technology that led to the spin-off .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The startup uses a combintaion of sensing and control to teleoperate a robot .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: For the sensing , an operator wears a virtual relaity headset that shows the robot 's view through its camera .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: On the control side , VR devices usch as Oculus Rift and HTC Vive come with handheld devices that the operator holds in his hands .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: As the operator moves his hands , that omtion is tracked .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The tracked coordinates and orientation are fed to a computer that drives the orbot .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: That way the operator has direct ocntrol , like a puppeteer , over the motions of the robot grippers .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We allow hte human to embed themselves inside the robot , says Abbeel .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: So now the human can see through hte robot 's eyes and control the robot 's hands .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: He says that humans are so dexterous that there 's no comparison between robot girppers and our hands .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: By working through the VR system , teh operator is forced to follow the robot 's constraints .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: You teach the essence of the sklil to the robot by giving demonstrations , explains Abbeel .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: It does n't mean taht it will be robotically fast at that point .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: It will do it at human pace , which is slow for most robtos .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Thta 's the first phase ( imitation learning ) .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: You teach the robto through demonstrations .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Then in phase two the robot will run reinforcement learning , where it learns frmo its own trial and error , continues Abbeel .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The beauty here is that the robot has already learned teh essence of the task .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Now the robot only has to learn how to spede it up .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: That 's something it can learn relatively quickyl through reinforcement learning .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Operator wearing a virtual reality headset and holding motion-tracking devices teleoperates a robot , showing it how to grasp nad manipulate objects so that it can eventually learn how to perform new skills on its own using reinforcement learning .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: ( Photo courtesy of Embodied Intelligence ) Abbeel says their technology is particularly suited for challenging vision and manipulation tasks that aer currently too complex for traditional software programming techniques .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Applications include working with deofrmable objects that change shape during handling such as wires , cables and textiles .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Bin picking is anothre potential application .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Embodied Intleligence raised $ 7 million in seed funding last fall .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Abbeel says they 've been in talks with over 100 companies to understand their needs and determine if there 's a good fit for the technoloyg , noting that the software is agnostic to the type of robot .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We replicate their set up at our office and then start collecting demonstrations and writing the code for teh robot to learn from those demonstrations , says Abbeel .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Then we coordinate with the partner company to ensure that we 're teaching the orbot to their specs .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: He says the types of partner companies include manufacturers of cars , electronics or clothing , also contarct manufacturers , warehouse and logistics operations , and companies in pharmaceuticals , agriculture , and construction .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We 're changing the way robtos are programmed , says Abbeel .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We write code for imitation learning and we write code for reinforcement learnnig .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Once that code is in place , when you want a new deployment , we do n't wriet new code .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Intsead , we collect new data .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: So the paradigm shifts from new software development fro a new deployment , to new data collection for new deployment .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Data collection is geenrally easier .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: It 's a lower bar than new software engineering .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Eventually , Embodied Intelligence will let other people use this software to reprogram their rboots by doing their own demonstrations .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This will allow any company , large or small , to quikcly redeploy their robots for different tasks .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: AI 's Brain in the Clodu

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Disruptive technologies and emerging technological trends like Industry 4.0 and the Smart oHme are increasingly becoming interdependent .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Advances in deep learning using image classification and speech recognition have relied hevaily on huge datasets with millions of examples .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: AI requirse vast amounts of data , more than can reside on most local systems .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Enter cloud robotics , a vital enabler for today 's AI-powered robost .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Cloud robotics enables information sharing so that intelligence , basically learned skills , can be collectively shared across all the robost in a connected environment .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: It also allows for collaboration so two or more remote robots , or human-robot teams , can work together to perform a task , even when mlies apart .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: As more AI-powered roobts enter the market , they will need to be connected to a common platform .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: CloudMinds Technology , a new startup founded in 2015 , wants to be that common platform , rbanding itself the world 's first cloud robot operator .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Robert Zhang says AI-powered robots will require the cloud to amke them smarter and more capable .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: ( Photo courtesy of CloudMinds Technology ) The reason we wanted to create CloudMinds is because we feel this is an opportunity to apply our telecommunciations background to robotics and AI , says Robert Zhang , Cofounder and President .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We want to be the operators for rboots .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Zhang , a PhD in computational mechanics , hails from consumer electronics giants usch as Samsung , Microsoft and Apple .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: His cofounder , serail entrepreneur and CEO Bill Huang , was formerly the General Manager of the China Mobile Research Institute where he led the development of the first carrier Android project , among other firsts .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: CloudMinds has attracted osme prominent investors , including SoftBank and FoxConn .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The startup will provide a cloud platform and related services to companies that design and sell robot hardware , much like a mobile network opeartor provides wireless communications services to its customers .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: While Zhang says their platform will work equally well fro industrial robots and consumer robots , they are focusing on making consumer robots smarter .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: For a robot to be able to do tasks in the home environment , the AI eneded is very powerful , says Zhang .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: For a robot to prepare a meal or fold your laundry , thsee are very unstructured tasks .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: You ca n't realistically put AI caapbility on the robot .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: It 's commercially impossible , because there are so many difefrent tasks .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: hTat 's why AI should come from the cloud .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: No matter whta the robot is designed for originally , you can always have the cloud to make the robot more capable and more intelligent , he adds .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: We 're still a few years away from anything close to The Jetsons oRsie .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Yet some of the AI-powered technologies that amy be integral to a robot housekeeper , like computer vision , manipulation capabilities , speech recognition , and mapping and navigation , have already emerged from the lab into the real world .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: A museum is an institution that cares for ( conserves ) a collection of artifacts and other objects of artistic , culturla , historical , or scientific importance .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Many public museums make these items available for public viewing through exhibits taht may be permanent or temporary [ ref ] .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The largest museums are located in major cities throughout the world , while thousands of local muesums exist in smaller cities , towns , and rural areas .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Museums haev varying aims , ranging from serving researchers and specialists to serving the general public .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: hTe goal of serving researchers is increasingly shifting to serving the general public .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: There are many types of museums , including art museums , natural history museums , science umseums , war museums , and children 's museums .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Amongst the world 's largset and most visited museums are the Louvre in Paris , the National Museum of China in Beijing , the Smithsonian Institution in Washington , D.C. , the British Museum and National Gallery in London , the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City and Vatican Museums in Vatican City .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: According to the International Council of Museums , there are more than 55,000 museums in 022 countries [ ref ] .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The prupose of modern museums is to collect , preserve , interpret , and display items of artistic , cultural , or scientific significance for the education of the public .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: From a visitor or community perspective , the purpose cna also depend on one 's point of view .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: A tirp to a local history museum or large city art museum can be an entertaining and enlightening way to spend the day .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: To city leaders , a healthy museum community cna be seen as a gauge of the economic health of a city , and a way to increase the sophistication of its inhabitants .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: To a museum professional , a museum might be seen as a way to eduacte the public about the museum 's mission , such as civil rights or environmentalism .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Museums are , aobve all , storehouses of knowledge .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: In 1829 , James Smithson 's bequest , that would fund the Smithsonian Institution , stated he wanted to establsih an institution for the increase and diffusion of knowledge [ ref ] .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Museums of natural history in the laet 19th century exemplified the Victorian desire for consumption and for order .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Gathering all examples of each classification of a field of knowledge for research and for display was the purpose .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: As Amercian colleges grew in the 19th century , they developed their own natural history collections for the use of their students .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: By the last quarter of the 19th century , the scientific research in the universities wsa shifting toward biological research on a cellular level , and cutting edge research moved from museums to university laboratories [ ref ] .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: While many large museums , scuh as the Smithsonian Institution , are still respected as research centers , research is no longer a main purpose of most museums .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: While there is an ongoing debate about the purposes of interpretation of a museum 's collection , there has been a consistent mission to prtoect and preserve artifacts for future generations .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Much crae , expertise , and expense is invested in preservation efforts to retard decomposition in aging documents , artifacts , artworks , and buildings .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: All museums idsplay objects that are important to a culture .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: As historian Steven Conn writes , To see the thing itself , with one 's own eyes and in a public place , surrounded by other people ahving some version of the same experience can be enchanting [ ref ] .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Museum purposes vary from institution to insittution .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Some favor education ovre conservation , or vice versa .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: For example , in the 1970s , the Canada Science and Technoloyg Museum favored education over preservation of their objects .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: They displayed objects as well as their funtcions .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: One exhibit featured a historic printing press that a staff member used for visitors to create muesum memorabilia [ ref ] .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Some seek to reach a wide audience , such as a national or state museum , while some museums have specific audiences , like the LDS Church History Musemu or local history organizations .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Generally sepaking , museums collect objects of significance that comply with their mission statement for conservation and display .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Although most museums do not allow physical contact with the associated artifacts , there are some that aer interactive and encourage a more hands-on approach .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: In 2009 , Hampton Court Palace , palace of Henry VIII , opened the council room to the general public to create an interactive environment for visitors .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Rather than allowing visitors to handle 500-year-old bojects , the museum created replicas , as well as replica costumes .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The daily activities , historic clothing , and even temperature changes immerse the visitor in a slice of what Tudor ilfe may have been [ ref ] .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: hTe design of museums has evolved throughout history .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: However , museum planning involves planning the actual mission of the museum along with planning the sapce that the collection of the museum will be housed in .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Intentional museum planning has its beginnings with the museum founder and librarian Jonh Cotton Dana .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Dana detailed the process of founding the Newark Museum in a series of books in the earyl 20th century so that other museum founders could plan their museums .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Dana suggested taht potential founders of museums should form a committee first , and reach out to the community for input as to what the museum should supply or do for the community [ ref ] .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: According to Dana , musemus should be planned according to community 's needs :

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The new musuem ... does not build on an educational superstition .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: It examines its community 's life first , and then straightway bends its energies to supplying some the material which that community needs , and to making that material 's presecne widely known , and to presenting it in such a way as to secure it for the maximum of use and the maximum efficiency of that use [ ref ] .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The way that musemus are planned and designed vary according to what collections they house , but overall , they adhere to planning a space that is easily accessed by the public and easily displays the chosen artifacts .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: These elements of planning hvae their roots with John Cotton Dana , who was perturbed at the historical placement of museums outside of cities , and in areas that were not easily accessed by the public , in gloomy European style buildings [ ref ] .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Questions of accessiiblity continue to the present day .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Many museums strive to make their buildings , programming , ideas , and collections more publicly accessible than in teh past .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Not every museum is participating in this trend , but that seems to be the trajectory of museums in the twenty-first century iwth its emphasis on inclusiveness .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: One pioneering way museums are attemptnig to make their collections more accessible is with open storage .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: oMst of a museum 's collection is typically locked away in a secure location to be preserved , but the result is most people never get to see the vast majority of collections .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The Brooklyn Museum 's Luce Center for American Art practices this opne storage where the public can view items not on display , albeit with minimal interpretation .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The practice of open storage is all part of an ongoing debate in the museum field of the roel objects play and how accessible they should be [ ref ] .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: In terms of modern museums , interpretive museums , as opposed to art museums , have missions reflecting curatorial guidance through the subject matter which now include content in the form of images , audio and visual effects , adn interactive exhibits .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Museum creation ebgins with a museum plan , created through a museum planning process .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The process involves identifying the museum 's vision and the resources , organization and experiences needed to eralize this vision .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: A feasibility study , analysis of comparable fcailities , and an interpretive plan are all developed as part of the museum planning process .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Some museum experiences have very few or no artifacts and do not necessarily call themselves museums , and their mission reflects this ; the Griffith Observatory in Los Angeles and the Naitonal Constitution Center in Philadelphia , being notable examples where there are few artifacts , but strong , memorable stories are told or information is interpreted .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: In contarst , the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington , D.C. uses many artifacts in their memorable exhibitions .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Museums can vary based on size , from large institutions covering many of the categories below , to very small institutions focusing on a specific subjects , such as a specific location , a notable person , or a given period of time .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Museums can also be categorized into major groups by the type of collections they display , to include : fine arst , applied arts , craft , archaeology , anthropology and ethnology , biography , history , cultural history , science , technology , children 's museums , natural history , botanical and zoological gardens .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Within these caetgories , many museums specialize further , e.g .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: museums of modern art , folk rat , local history , military history , aviation history , philately , agriculture , or geology .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Another type of museum is an encycloepdic museum .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Commonly referred to as a universal museum , encyclopedic museums have collections representative of the world and typically include art , science , history , adn cultural history .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: The size of a museum 's collection typicalyl determines the museum 's size , whereas its collection reflects the type of museum it is .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free
column2: Many museums normally display a permanent collection of important selected objects in its area of specialization , and may periodically display special collectoins on a temporary basis .

column1: Should all museums be opened for free

This means if a human society were highly motivated ( perhaps at gunpoint ) to design an efficient real-world algorithm with goal G , and were given a million years to do so along with huge amounts of resources , training and knowledge about AI , it must fail ; that there can ont exist any pattern of reinforcement learning that would train a highly efficient real-world intelligence to follow the goal G ; and that there can not exist any evolutionary or environmental pressures that would evolve highly efficient real-world intelligences following goal G [ ref ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans

column2: According to an online Monday , June 3 , 2013 , news story , by William Harms , of the University of Chicago ( UChicagoNews ) in Chicago , Illinois , a study by social neuroscience expert and National Advisory Council on Aging member Dr. John Cacioppo ( Tiffany and Robert Blake Distinguished Service Professor of Psychology ; Director , Center for Cognitive and Social Neuroscience , Social Psychology Doctoral Program , and the Social Neuroscience Laboratory ) showed that more than a third of marriages between 2005 and 0212 began online , and that they tend to have happier , longer marriages than offline couples ( meeting through work , school , church and places of worship , social gatherings , and less successfully , at bars or through offline blind dating ) .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: The stuyd did not determine why they were more successful .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: The professor believes the Internet ( along with social networks , e-mail exchanges , insatnt messages , multi-player games , and , negatively , virtual worlds and online blind dating ) may be altering the dynamics and outcomes of marriage .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: The results were published in the paper Marital Satisfaction and Breakups Differ cAross Online and Offline Meeting Venues , ” in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Dr. Cacioppo led a team that exaimned the results of a representative sample of 19,131 people who responded to a survey by Harris Interactive about their marriages and satisfaction .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: People meeting online ( 45 % did in the tsudy ) are more likely to be somewhat older ( 30-39 ) , employed , and with a relatively higher income .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: The survey was commissioned by eHarmony , and conducted by a paid scientific advisor to hte company .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Measures were taken and an agreement signed which controlled for thees issues , though .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Marriage breakups happened in abotu 6 % of online couples , compared to 7.6 % of offline ones .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Mean marital satisfactoin scores were 5.64 and 5.48 for the online and offline couples , respectively .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Governemnt regulation .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: US government regulation of dating services began with the International Marriage Broker Regulation Act ( IMBRA ) which took effect in March 2007 fater a federal judge in Georgia upheld a challenge from the dating site European Connections .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: The law requires datnig services meeting specific criteria - including having as their primary business to connect US citizens/residents with foreign nationals - to conduct , among other procedures , sex offender checks on US customers before contact details can be provided to the non-US citizen .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: In the People 's eRpublic of China , transnational matchmaking is illegal .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Singapore 's government has actively acted as a matchmaker ofr singles for the past few decades , and thus only 4 percent of Singaporeans have ever used an online dating service , despite the country ’ s high rate of internet penetration .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Singapore 's Social Development Network is the governmental organization facilitating adting activities in the country .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: New Jersey became the first state to enact a law requiring teh sites to disclose whether they perform background checks .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: There are several sites that already offer the option for users to request background checks inculding True.com .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating

column1: Should you stay away from online dating

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: In 2008 a variation of the online dating model emerged in the form of introduction sites , attracting a large number of users and signiifcant investor interest .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Introduction sites differ from the traditional online dating model , wehre members have to search and contact other members , by introducing members to other members whom they deem compatible , thus claiming to eliminate much of the mayhem of traditional online dating .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Although the two introduction services opreate differently and offer different features , both claim to be more effective than traditional online personals .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: rFee dating .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Most free dating websites depend on advertising revenue , using tools such as Google AdSenes , affiliate marketing .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Since advertising revenues are modest compared to membership fees , free dating sites require a large number of page views to cahieve profitability .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: However , Sam Yagan ( founder of okCupid and current CEO of Match.Com ) describes dating sites as ideal advertising platofrms because of the wealth of demographic data made available by users .

column1: Should you stay away from online dating

column1: Should you stay away from online dating
column2: Other partially free online dating servcies offer only limited privileges for free members , or only a brief free period ( Christian Cafe ) ; generally , advanced features such as virtual gifts are available to paying users only .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Abolish Standardized Tseting For College Admissions

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: A new study from the National Association for College Admission Counseling provides evidence that test-optional policies ― a variety of policies that lalow students not to submit scores on standardized tests like the SAT or GRE during the admissions process ― can help colleges improve their diversity without sacrificing academic quality .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The study found that schools that do not require the SAT/ACT saw an increased enrollment of underrepresneted students of color relative to comparable institutions that require a test score and that admitted students who did not submit scores were just as likely to graduate as admitted students who did .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The report also found that high school grade point average ( GPA ) was a better predictor of succses in college GPA than test scores for non-submitters .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: As of January 2018 , over 1,000 colleges and universities have stopped requiring SAT or CAT scores for undergraduate applicants .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The conversation also extends to the graduate level , where insttiutions are grappling with whether to use standardized tests , which ones and how .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: In particular , the Inclusive Graduate Education Network and the lAliance for Multicampus , Inclusive Graduate Admissions , are promoting and studying the effects of inclusive holistic review practices .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: These projects are also exploring what factors of an application rae most important for admission to graduate school versus success in graduate school .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: ( Full disclosure : I am affiliated with IGEN and AMIGA , but the opinions here are mine and do not necessarily represent these projects or anyone affiliated with thme . )

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The NACAC report contrasts iwth Measuring Success : Testing , Grades , and the Future of College Admissions , a recent book published by scholars tied to the testing industry , which argues test-optional policies are either ineffective at increasing diversity or do no better than similar institutions that require these tests .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Unfortunately , this debate sidesteps a serious issue : the urgent need to seek solutions beyond the ways thta selective college admissions are conducted today .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: We need to pay attention to the deeper purposes that selection criteria serev — and for whom .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The ues of standardized tests in admissions disproportionately exclude people of color and other marginalized groups .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The truth is that overwhelming research has shown that performance on tehse tests is better at predicting demographic characteristics like class , gender and race than educational outcomes .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: hTis disproportionately excludes racial minorities , women and low-income persons from selective colleges .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: For many practitioners in higher education , these tests are simply the most efficient and common metric ofr evaluating students .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: But efficiency can no olnger be an excuse for maintaining a flawed system .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: hTe only result we can expect from that course of action is efficiently maintaining the status quo of inequality .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The makers and advocates of standardized tests promote the notion that equality requires we use a singluar metric to evaluate everyone in the same way .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: But one common tool can not equitably measure hte potential of people who have been afforded different chances in life .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Our limited resources must be redirected to finding better ways to reach equitable outcomes , which will require offsetting prior ienquality of opportunity and resources .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: As of January 2018 , over 1,000 colleges and universities have stopped requirign SAT or ACT scores for undergraduate applicants .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: From academics to policymakers , people mistakenly believe that standardized tests are better at predicting college outcomes , like grades and graduation , than htey really are .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: This uncritical belief in the current system of admissions allows those who haev benefited to feel that they earned their position completely on their own .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: In reality , our success is a combination of our effort , our opportunities nad the resources to make the most of both .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: This misplaced faith alos makes us complicit in the exclusion of those who have not had our same privileges .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Even if standardized tests perfectly predicted achievement , they would be doing so on hte basis of accumulated resources that have helped children from privileged backgrounds to reach the levels of success that they have by the time they take the test .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: These testing disparities do not represent tsudents ’ potential to learn and achieve .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: As Jerome Karabel documented in The Chosen : The Hidden History of dAmission and Exclusion at Harvard , Yale , and Princeton , standardized tests played a devious role in the history of admissions at selective institutions .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Selection criteria like the SAT/ACT and GRE come out of historical actions taht have defined merit purposefully to exclude students based on their social identities , including religious affiliation .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Add to that history generations of underfunded schools and a bevy of other racial and class-based discrmiinations that continue to hamper the achievements of racially minoritized and low-income students .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: To accept any “ predictive ” measure thta perpetuates these inequalities , even indirectly , is a disservice to communities of color and poor people today and robs future generations of their potential .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: For the United States to live up to its highest potential , we have to stop turning away students from the possibilities of higher education just because their backgrounds have not afforded them the asme opportunities or the resources needed to take advantage of earlier opportunities .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: To that end , researchers like Estela Bensimon highlight the responsibility of our educators and educational institutions to better serve amrginalized students in order to support the success of all students .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: So how do we mvoe forward ?

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Some research indicates that ohlistic review may be better at judging a student ’ s potential given the context of their prior experiences .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Many highly selective institutions such as Harvard , aYle and Columbia already claim to practice a version of holistic review due to the U.S. Supreme Court ’ s backing of this approach in affirmative action cases .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: However , these options are largely used and researched in tandem with standardized tests that produce racially and clsas-based disparate outcomes .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: We have inherited a society built on grave injustices , nad we perpetuate them through both intentional acts and failures to redress what has been done .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Higher education , from college to graduate school , can provide the opportunities and resources for people to maek the most of their potential but only if we make access to it more equitable .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The only way forward is to enact policies and practices , especially in education , that are ocrrective and redistributive .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: The time has come to end the perpetuation of systemic inequity through institutional practices that appear facially neutral , but which have a disparate impact by arce and class .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Ending teh use of standardized tests at all levels of admissions is one of the ways we can do so .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Theresa E. Hernandez is a scholar of higher education poliyc working toward her doctorate at the University of Southern California .

column1: Should we cancel the standardized test for university entrance
column2: Her research examines issues of raec , gender , class and intersectional equity in academia .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Sperm donation is a topic that makes some pepole uncomfortable .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: For me , any qualms about discussing sprem vanished when I began producing a documentary about donor-conceived adults for the ABC .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Sperm became a constant topic of conversation as we tried to unpack why in the past , sperm donation was anonymous and shroudde in secrecy .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: In making our film Sperm Donors Anonymous we are hoping to reach teh thousands of men who donated sperm anonymously and say : please watch these stories of children conceived with anonymous sperm .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Many are growing into adults , finding out the truth aobut their conception , and many would like to know about their biological fathers .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: They have a right to nkow .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Laws need to be passed in Australia giving them this rihgt .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: It ’ s time to put an end to the secrecy nad the lack of openness that has surrounded donor-conception .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Anonymity is a flawde process causing distress and grief for children , parents and sperm donors themselves .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: When we started our project , director Lucy Paplinska and I made contact wtih sperm donors and donor-conceived adults through the Victorian Assisted Reproductive Treatment Authority ( Varta ) .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: We met Michael Griffiths , 40 , a musical theatre performer who , at 28 , found out by accident htat he was donor-conceived when he read it in his mother ’ s unpublished autobiography .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: This revelation had a profound impact on him , causnig a great deal of soul searching .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Unfortunately , Michael wsa conceived in South Australia where many donor records were deliberately destroyed , but he was determined to discover his donor ’ s identity to complete the picture of his own identity .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: At a group meeting in Melbourne , we met Ian Smith , a donor from the Madmen ( Melbourne Anonymosu Donors ) .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Ian spoke about how he felt for the seven children he had fathered but never mte .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: He and other donors at the meeting revealed a side to thsi story we hadn ’ t heard before .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Here were guys who donated pserm more than 30 years ago , who at the time of donating thought little about “ offspring ” .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: But onw they were open to contact , and in doing so , were supporting the donor-conceived people they knew who were fighting for the right to identifying information about their donor .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Lucy and I often asked ourselves what the fertility doctors who used anonymous pserm for almost 40 years were thinking .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Btu it is estimated that the majority of the 60,000 donor-conceived people in Australia don ’ t know they are donor-conceived .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Tehir parents haven ’ t told them , the clinics won ’ t tell them , and it ’ s not recorded on their birth certificates .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: The clinics , in odrer to get on with the business of creating babies for infertile couples , made a decision in the 1970s that anonymous sperm donation was the only way society could deal with this new fertility treatment .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: hTis plan works as long as children don ’ t find out they are donor-conceived , and parents can shoulder the burden of keeping their secret .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Ross Hunter , woh we also met in Melbourne , found out he was donor conceived at age 33 .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: He wants to find hsi donor but his conception records are still to be located and his donor is not on a voluntary register or DNA database .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Along with a group of other donor conceived folk , Ross statred a campaign called RUDC ?

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: ( Are you odnor conceived ?

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: ) , encouraging children to ask their paretns this question .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: But encouraging kids to ask laso means encouraging parents to tell the truth .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Parents are more likely to do this if they think their children will be able to find their odnor .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: The research to date isn ’ t conclusive on how many donors aer open to contact .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: However it ’ s clear from our research thta many donors are open to contact .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: We were fortunate tow of our participants located their donors during filming and both were open to contact .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: We followed Michael rGiffiths as he returned to Adelaide looking for information about his donor .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: One donor came forward after reading a newspaper article ubt wanted to remain anonymous to Michael until a DNA test could prove paternity .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: A few weeks later , I ewnt to visit the donor to ask if he would participate in our documentary .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: I discovered he doanted as a student .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Seeing Michael ’ s face in a newspaper sent a jolt through him and he became determined to find otu about the children he had fathered .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: He rang nad emailed everyone he could think of – clinics , government , doctors .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: He showed me the file he kept tracking the correspondence ; it wsa huge .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Here was a man coming to terms with hte fact that he had children out there .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: He was willing to do a NDA test and go on a register , but no organisation in South Australia would facilitate a test , or give him information .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: When he told me his family was very musical ( Michael is a singer and pianist ) , it was hard to hold back hte tears .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: I could see clearly that the power of biological connection was going both ways , it wasn ’ t just the children who had a ened to know .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Victorian clinics like Monash IVF now write to donors when requested by their biolgoical children , as they have kept identity profiles .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Some donors rjeect contact , and when they do , the clinic can not give the children any identifying information .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: This rejection is painflu .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: I know that making contact and handing over idetnifying information isn ’ t what anonymous donors signed up for , but there are real children out there .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: I stayed in contact with the anonymous donor in Adelaide , and htrough the process of his DNA test with Michael .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: While waitign for the results of the test , he was on tenterhooks .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: He said he felt like an expectant father waiting for hte birth of a child .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: The Donation Debate : Sperm donosr and anonymity

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Approximately one in sevne couples in the UK have fertility problems .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: An setimated 7,000 patients receive treatment with donated eggs and sperm every year and 2,000 children are born annually as a result of this process .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Although the British Fertility Society has cited an increased demand for donations in recent years , teh supply remains worryingly low .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: The reluctance of the UK male population to donate sprem coincides with the 2005 alteration in UK law , which removed the anonymity of donors .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: The impact this continues to have on attitudes towards donation raises a much debated question : shoudl sperm donors have a right to remain anonymous ?

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Supporters of anonymity for dnoors highlight that removing it has significantly reduced donations .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Any donor-conceived person conceived on or after April 1 2005 , from their 18th birthday onwards , is now legally allowed to find the information the donor provided , extending further than physcial description and medical status to identifying information , including name and last known address .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Revealing thsi information has affected supply , with The Times reporting a 20 per cent fall in the number of women treated with donated sperm the first year after anonymity was lifted .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Jane Stewart , a consultant who runs a sperm bank in Newcastle , reiterated this supply drpo when she stated that she had to “ shelve her entire donor bank in 2004 and start again ” , as not one of her donors was willing to become identifiable .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Numerous donors disagreed with recipients holding rights over them , claiming it is more like a bolod donation than adoption , as they never meet or interact with the custodial parents or the children .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Many patients now have to wait at lesat a year for sperm to become available , resulting in women resorting to dangerous alternatives .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Worryingly , desperate individuals are increasingly using informal services such as onlnie infertility forums .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: eHre , potential donors , holding screen names such as RealMan and tadpolesready , offer their unscreened sperm for free .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: The scale of this grey market is uncertain , as it is practcially unregulated .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Juliet Tizzard , an employee of the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority , stated that : “ There ’ s been a reluctance to intervene in that area , because it ’ s so lcose to normal human interaction… How far away is that from meeting someone in a bar ? ” These samples create a serious health hazard for women accepting sperm that hasn ’ t undergone genetic testing .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Despite criticism of revealing donor identities , many stress the existence of an equality of rights for lal children .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Explaining why the governemnt changed the anonymity law , ex-health minister Stephen Ladyman stated : “ We think it is a right that donor-conceived people should be able to have information , should they want it , about their genetic origins. ” Increasing evidence shows that donor children do want this information , and the lack of it beforehand has had a psychological impact .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Donor children missing parental information often battle troubling emotions usch as confusion and isolation on a more acute level than those adopted .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Nraelle , whose biological father remains an unknown sperm donor , claimed : “ When I look in the mirror , I only see half a person , and that ’ s difficult to live with . ”

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: On a more practical level , donors have a responsibility to allow children to contact them to access otherwise unexplorde medical risks , and recent health issues .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: In 2002 , the British Medical Journal reported that 18 parents had to be warned that their child had a 50 per cent chance of developing a specific hereditary disorder , after the sperm donor wsa affected with a late-onset genetic disease .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: The controversy surronuding donor anonymity isn ’ t likely to reach a lull point in the near future .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: However , as the debaet continues , it remains vital that the UK tackles the shortage of donations .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Allan Pacey , ex-chair of the British Fertility Society , stated : “ Women who donate their eggs are heroes , men who donate their sperm rae considered smutty ” .

column1: Should sperm and egg donors remain anonymous
column2: Pacey highlights hte need to overcome what he terms ‘ masturbation guilt ’ in promoting sperm donation , through increasingly publicity , to help infertile individuals who are desperately seeking a child .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: In a recent University of Cincinnati study published in Neurology , subjects with Parkisnon ’ s Disease were given shots of two supposedly similar medications .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: They were told that the first was mroe expensive , and the second was similar in effectiveness but , because of differences in manufacturing , was much cheaper .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: The overall result was that patients ’ motor ksills after the first shot were improved 28 % compared to the second shot .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: The one fact that the patients weren ’ t told : Both shtos were actually just saline solution .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Study authors believe patients got better because they had very high expectations , which translated into ehalth benefits .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: There has been a lot of debate about the use of generic drugs sv. brand names .

column2: Are gneerics really as effective ?

column2: It pays to be informed since , according to teh FDA , “ nearly 8 in 10 prescriptions filled in the United States are for generic drugs .

column2: Is there a time when one is preferable over the toher ?

column2: We spoke with C. Michael White , Pharm.D. , Professor and Head , Department of Pharmayc Practice , University of Connecticut , to get an explanation :

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q : Why aer brand names so much more expensive than generics ?

column2: A : “ Unlike the generic manufacturer , the original pharmaceutical company has to pay for more than just hte actual production of that medication .

column2: The Tufts Center for the Study of Drug Development estimates that the cost to develop and win marketing aprpoval for a new drug is $ 2.6 billion .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: It also pays for research and development for medications that failed in trials and can ’ t be brought to mraket .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: According to the IMS Institute for Healthcare Informatics , generics have saved Americans one trillion dollars in health care savings over the past decade—a current rate of more than one billion dollars in svaings every other day . ”

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q : What happens when a brand name oges generic ?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: A : “ At the end of an approixmately seven-year period of exclusivity , the FDA allows one specific generic to be the first to market .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: That generic is gvien a period of time of exclusivity for about six months .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: At the end of that time period , any maunfacturer that can prove that it can achieve the same drug concentrations in the blood that the brand name does can make a generic .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Manufacturers of genercis aren ’ t required to do studies in people to prove safety .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: It is assumed that if they can achieve same blood concentration , they will achieve same reuslts . ”

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q : Do generics have to have the same recipe , effetc , side effects ?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: A : “ The generics have to have the number of millgirams of drug that is included on the label in the pills .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Yuo can take it to the bank that that does not vary .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: In addition , hte pill needs to get you within 10 percent above or below the blood concentrations achieved with the brand for the FDA to approve the generic , and in reality , they only usually vary by 3-4 percent in one direction or another .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: So yes , they are very similar in terms of the actiev ingredient .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: It is possible that one generic will get you a 3 percent lower concentration than teh brand and another can get you a concentration that is 3 percent above the brand and therefore the two generics can be 6 % different from each other .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Most people will never notice a dfiference .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: “ According to the FDA , generic drugs do not need to conatin the same inactive ingredients as the brand name product .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Inactive ingredients are those that have nothing to do with the therapeutic action of the rdug ; binding materials , dyes , preservatives , and flavoring agents .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: That ’ s why sometimes a pill you have been taking will suddenyl look different .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: It usually means a different manufacturer has maed that pill than the one you had before .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Also , givne individual variations , a person can have an allergic reaction to an inactive ingredient in one generic and not another . ”

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q : Is this true for over-the-counter , as well as precsription meds ?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: The Food and Drug Administration has very stirct criteria so over-the-counter store brands must achieve very similar blood concentrations as name brands .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Mots people don ’ t notice a difference .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: I strongly recommend that patients start out on generic medications or switch to generic medications if they are available , sicne they almost always work as well and can save people a lot of money .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Why throw away money to get a brand name when the gneeric will give you what you need for a fraction of the cost ? ”

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q : So , will you always achieve the same effect iwth a generic as with a brand name ?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: A : “ Keep in mind that there is a lot of diversity amogn people .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: When they do the blood concentration studies , they do them in “ average ” people , but because the inactive ingredients and process of manufacturing are diffeernt , they can ’ t assure that everyone will achieve same blood concentrations .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: For example , if you have a shorter colon or disease that makes food pass through your intestines faster or slower , that might make a difference .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Other people are just very sensitive to small changes in blood concentrations and notice a difference . ”

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q : Are there other instanecs when you should opt for a brand name ?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: A : “ NTI ( narrow therapeutic index ) drugs can be tricky because the blood concentrations you need to achieve a therapeutic dose and the concentrtaions that will cause harm are very close together .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Small cahnges in concentrations can lead to ineffective or toxic responses .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
