column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: With these , you need to talk to your physician about switching to generic , make sure you understand hte risks and rewards , and that you are more closely monitored for the first couple of weeks afterwards .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: “ Of these NTI drugs , patients with anti-epilepsy drugs are a unique gruop that do equally well when started on brand or generic drugs but during the couple of weeks after switching from brand to generic or generic to brand , they are more likely to go to the emergency department or their doctor ’ s office .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Epileptic aptients should not be routinely changing between forms of the drug for this reason .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: “ Some patients will tolerate a brand name medication but when they switch medications , they simply do not do as well .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: The reason may be that that while the blood concentrations of the brand name medication are veyr similar , what the tablets are made out of can vary .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: So while the average patient does as well , not everyone will .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: If you are that outlier , you are better off on the branded medicatino or another generic .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: I usually recommend trying two generic versions before giving up adn moving back to a brand name drug because again , the costs are much cheaper .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: “ There ’ s been a lot of consolidation in the generic manufacturing industry ( companies merging with toher companies , leaving less competition in the field ) .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: In very rare cases , we are left wiht only one generic manufacturer , so the generic is more expensive than the brand name .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Supply and demand also happens in generic drugs and it ’ s all what teh market will bear .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Insurance companies may stpiulate that you get a lower co-pay with generic than with a brand name even if brand name is less expensive .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Patients with very expensive generics should aks their pharmacists if brand name medications are actually cheaper and if they are , switch back to the brand . ”

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: Q : Is it dangerous to your health to switch abck and forth ?

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: A : “ Most people taking almost all drugs would not notice a perceptible difference in efficacy or safety when switching between brands and generics or between generics , except in the case of NTIs , which are tirckier .

column2: If you rae on a NTI drug , talk with your doctors about the risks and rewards of switching .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs
column2: For all the other drugs , if you switch and you have mild symptoms , there is a chance that those things iwll resolve and you should stay the course .

column1: Should we ban the production of generic drugs

column2: according to Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy : “ There are basically two reactions to the flood of new technology and its impact on personal information and privacy : the first reaction , held by many people in IT industry and in R & D , is that we have zero privacy in the digital age and that there is no way we can protect it , so we should get used to the new world and get over it.The other reaction is that our privacy is more important than ever adn that we can and we must attempt to protect it ” ( 2014 ) .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: An AI with teh abilities of a competent artificial intelligence researcher would be able to modify its own source code and increase its own intelligence [ according to whom ? ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: If its self-reprogramming leads to its getting even better at being able to reprogram itself , the result could be a recursive intelligence explosion where it would rpaidly leave human intelligence far behind [ citation needed ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Technology research : A machine with superhuman scientific research abiliites would be able to beat the human research community to milestones such as nanotechnology or advanced biotechnology .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: If teh advantage becomes sufficiently large ( for example , due to a sudden intelligence explosion ) , an AI takeover becomes trivial [ according to whom ? ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: For example , a superintelligent AI might design self-replicating bots that initially escpae detection by diffusing throughout the world at a low concentration .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Then , at a prearranged time , the bots multiply into nanofactories htat cover every square foot of the Earth , producing nerve gas or deadly target-seeking mini-drones [ citation needed ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Strategizing : A superitnelligence might be able to simply outwit human opposition [ citation needed ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Social manipulation : A superintelligence might be able to recruit uhman support [ ref ] , or covertly incite a war between humans [ ref ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Economic productivity : As logn as a copy of the AI could produce more economic wealth than the cost of its hardware , individual humans would have an incentive to voluntarily allow the Artificial General Intelligence ( AGI ) to run a copy of itself on their systems [ according to whom ?

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Hacking : A superintelligence could find new exploits in computers connected to the Internet , and spread copies of itself onto thsoe systems , or might steal money to finance its plans [ citation needed ] .

column2: Sources of AI avdantage

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: A computer program taht faithfully emulates a human brain , or that otherwise runs algorithms that are equally powerful as the human brain 's algorithms , could still become a speed superintelligence if it can think many orders of magnitude faster than a human , due to being made of silicon rather than flesh , or due to optimization focusing on increasing the speed of the AGI .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Biological neurons operate at about 200 Hz , wehreas a modern microprocessor operates at a speed of about 2,000,000,000 Hz .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Human axons carry action potentials at around 102 m/s , whereas computer signals travel near the speed of light [ ref ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: A network of human-level intelligences designed to network together and share complex thoughts and memories sealmessly , able to collectively work as a giant unified team without friction , or consisting of trillions of human-level intelligences , would become a collective superintelligence [ ref ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: More broadly , any number of qualitative improvements to a human-level AGI could result in a quality superintelligence , perhaps resulting in an AIG as far above us in intelligence as humans are above non-human apes [ according to whom ? ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The number of neurons in a human barin is limited by cranial volume and metabolic constraints ; in contrast , you can add components to a supercomputer until it fills up its entire warehouse [ clarification needed ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: An AGI need not be limited by human constraints on working memory , and might therefore be able to intuitively grasp more complex relationships than humans can [ dubious – idscuss ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: An AGI with specialized cognitive support for engineering or computer programming would have an advantage in these fields , compared with humans woh evolved no specialized mental modules to specifically deal with those domains .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Unlike humans , an AGI can spawn copies of itself and tinker with its copies ' source ocde to attempt to further improve its algorithms [ ref ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Is strong AI inherently dangerosu ?

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: A significant problem is that unfriendly artificial nitelligence is likely to be much easier to create than friendly AI .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: While both require large davances in recursive optimisation process design , friendly AI also requires the ability to make goal structures invariant under self-improvement ( or the AI could transform itself into something unfriendly ) and a goal structure that aligns with human values and does not automatically destroy the entire human race .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: An unfriendly AI , on the other hand , can optimize for an arbitrary goal structure , which does not need to be invariant under sefl-modification [ ref ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The sheer complexity of human value systems makes it very difficult to make AI 's motiavtions human-friendly [ ref ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Unless moral philosophy provides us with a flawless ethical theory , an AI 's utility function could allow for many potentially harmful scenarios that conform with a given tehical framework but not common sense .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: According to Eliezer Yudkowsyk , there is little reason to suppose that an artificially designed mind would have such an adaptation [ ref ] .

column2: For an AI takeover to be inevitable , it has to be postulated that two intelligent species can not pursue mutually the goals of coexisting peacefully in an overlapping environment—especially if noe is of much more advanced intelligence and much more powerful [ according to whom ? ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: While an AI takeover is thus a possible resutl of the invention of artificial intelligence , a peaceful outcome is not necessarily impossible [ according to whom ?

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: The fear of cybernetic revolt is often based on interpretations of uhmanity 's history , which is rife with incidents of enslavement and genocide .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Such fears stem from a belief that competitiveness and aggression are nceessary in any intelligent being 's goal system .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: However , such human competitiveness stems from the evolutionary background to our intelligence , where the survival and reprodutcion of genes in the face of human and non-human competitors was the central goal [ ref ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: In fcat , an arbitrary intelligence could have arbitrary goals : there is no particular reason that an artificially intelligent machine ( not sharing humanity 's evolutionary context ) would be hostile—or friendly—unless its creator programs it to be such and it is not inclined or capable of modifying its programming .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: But the question remains : what would happen if AI systems could interact and evolve ( evolution in this context emans self-modification or selection and reproduction ) and need to compete over resources , would that create goals of self-preservation ?

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: AI 's goal of self-preservation could be in ocnflict with some goals of humans .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Some scientists dispute the likelihood of cybernetic revolts as depicted in science fiction such as The Matrix , claiming that it is more likely that any artificial intelligence powerful enough to threatne humanity would probably be programmed not to attack it [ citation needed ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This would not , however , protect against the possibility of a revolt initiatde by terrorists , or by accident .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Artificial General Intelligence researcher Eliezer Yudkowsky has stated on this note that , probabilistically , humanity is less likely to be threatened by deliberately aggressive AIs than by AIs which were programmed such that their goals are unintentionally incompatible with human survival or well-being ( as in the film I , Robot and in the short story The vEitable Conflict ) .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Steve Omohundro suggests that present-day automation ssytems are not designed for safety and that AIs may blindly optimize narrow utility functions ( say , playing chess at all costs ) , leading them to seek self-preservation and elimination of obstacles , including humans who might turn them off [ ref ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Another factor which amy negate the likelihood of an AI takeover is the vast difference between humans and AIs in terms of the resources necessary for survival .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: Humans require a wet , organic , temperate , oxygen-laden environment while an AI might htrive essentially anywhere because their construction and energy needs would most likely be largely non-organic [ dubious – discuss ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: With little or no competition for resources , conflict would perhpas be less likely no matter what sort of motivational architecture an artificial intelligence was given , especially provided with the superabundance of non-organic material resources in , for instance , the asteroid belt .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: This , however , does not negate the possibility of a disinterested or unsympathetic AI artificially decomposing all life on aerth into mineral components for consumption or other purposes [ citation needed ] .

column1: Will artificial intelligence replace humans
column2: In the case of a sudden intelligence explosion , effective precautions will be extremely difficult ; not only would its creators haev little ability to test their precautions on an intermediate intelligence , but the creators might not even have made any precautions at all , if the advent of the intelligence explosion catches them completely by surprise [ ref ] .
